subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test first? or Stub first?
msgSnippet: ... I dunno. All of this stuff where you write a stub and then get the idea to edit the stub for you as you play with ideas seems like a lot of work to me,
messageBody:
On Wed, 22 Jan 2003 steffen.gemkow@... wrote:

> > Also, if you haven't written the test, then how can you be sure that
> > the stub:
> >
> > 1. ...has the proper signature?
> > 2. ...is named well?
> > 3. ...should be class- or instance-level?
> > 4. ...is written on the appropriate object?
>
> At that point I'm not sure either. But with the skeleton of
> the application method in place, one can use the full power
> of the IDE. I'm using JUnitDoclet together with IDEA.
>
> [lots of stuff about the IDE changing stuff you've already written]

I dunno. All of this stuff where you write a stub and then get the idea
to edit the stub for you as you play with ideas seems like a lot of work
to me, compared to just sketching out the ideas right into a unit test.
Especially since you still have to type out the stubs initially.

Why futz about with special tools when they're completely unnecessary?
Just play about with your interface without any stubs at all, and write
them when you're happy with the bit of interface you've designed.

In fact, I often "test second" in that the usually place I first write
anything to do with a new class I'm thinking of creating is in the
class that uses it. I just imagine that my new magic class exists
and does what I need, and code that. Then I code up some unit tests
that parallel that, and then code the class itself. Works great, and
sometimes complete classes appear and disappear in the caller before I
really work out what interface I need; it would be a waste of time to
create stubs for a class and generate the test cases, only to delete all
of that five minutes later.

Also, I find my test cases often don't parallel the particular methods
of a class. They test the typical usage patterns of a class, instead. So
a test generator would just generate the wrong thing anyway.

But in the end, I guess you believe in test-first programming or you don't.
